text:
Hi!

We wanted to clarify a question regarding the deployment architecture, if possible.

As we're working on the deployment setup for our Catalyst Package Manager, I'm trying to understand the simplest deployment options that make sense. In this Canton deep dive session (<https://www.canton.network/tech-deep-dives-session-5>, starting from 9:30), the design implies that the app user only hosts the participant and DAR, while using a UI hosted by the app provider. However, to me it’s not quite clear how the app-provider-hosted UI is able to execute commands on multiple Ledger APIs hosted by different app users. Is there some kind of mechanism for registering the end users’ Ledger APIs on the app provider side, so the UI knows which Ledger API to call for each user?

According to the documentation ( <https://docs.digitalasset.com/build/3.3/sdlc-howtos/system-design/daml-app-arch-design#app-provider-operates-the-backend> ), the simplest option is described as: *The first option requires the fewest components to build, where app users operate only the frontends, while the app provider exclusively operates the backend.*

This suggests that each app user hosts their own UI that talks to their own Ledger API. That setup makes more sense to me, but it requires extra UI deployment  on the app user’s infrastructure and differs from the design shown in the deep dive video.

So I’m trying to understand: what design should we follow if we want to minimize deployment effort for end app users?

Thanks in advance!

elements.text:

We wanted to clarify a question regarding the deployment architecture, if possible.

As we're working on the deployment setup for our Catalyst Package Manager, I'm trying to understand the simplest deployment options that make sense. In this Canton deep dive session (

, starting from 9:30), the design implies that the app user only hosts the participant and DAR, while using a UI hosted by the app provider. However, to me it’s not quite clear how the app-provider-hosted UI is able to execute commands on multiple Ledger APIs hosted by different app users. Is there some kind of mechanism for registering the end users’ Ledger APIs on the app provider side, so the UI knows which Ledger API to call for each user?

According to the documentation (
), the simplest option is described as:
The first option requires the fewest components to build, where app users operate only the frontends, while the app provider exclusively operates the backend.

This suggests that each app user hosts their own UI that talks to their own Ledger API. That setup makes more sense to me, but it requires extra UI deployment  on the app user’s infrastructure and differs from the design shown in the deep dive video.

So I’m trying to understand: what design should we follow if we want to minimize deployment effort for end app users?

Thanks in advance!

text:
*Hi everyone,*
In our setup, the backend application runs on a local network, while the validator is deployed in the cloud. Is it possible to generate an admin access token locally (on the backend) and use it to authenticate gRPC requests to the validator — specifically for calling the `allocateParty` method?
If so, are there any recommended best practices or security considerations for generating and using such a token remotely?
Thanks in advance!

elements.text: Hi everyone,

In our setup, the backend application runs on a local network, while the validator is deployed in the cloud. Is it possible to generate an admin access token locally (on the backend) and use it to authenticate gRPC requests to the validator — specifically for calling the
allocateParty

method?
If so, are there any recommended best practices or security considerations for generating and using such a token remotely?
Thanks in advance!

text:
The codegen libraries that you get give you only a representation of the data layer (template and choice payloads) of your Daml models. The other libraries (@daml/types|ledger|react) build up to give you a programmable interface that makes calls against (ala for now only v1) JSON api of the participant node.

If you ever have to interact with the Daml model payloads it is pretty useful to get tab completion on payloads or tsc errors on missing choice parameters.

elements.text:
The codegen libraries that you get give you only a representation of the data layer (template and choice payloads) of your Daml models. The other libraries (@daml/types|ledger|react) build up to give you a programmable interface that makes calls against (ala for now only v1) JSON api of the participant node.

If you ever have to interact with the Daml model payloads it is pretty useful to get tab completion on payloads or tsc errors on missing choice parameters.
